reviews.review_title: A final ode to the wonderful Pat Morita as Mr Miyagi - thank you
reviews.content: Many may wish to give this film much criticism for various reasons, and yet there are actually moments of true beauty in this too, and that's what I want to mostly concentrate on here.The premise is clear and obvious to all even if they have not seen the original. What we have here is an ode to the wonderful Pat Morita playing Mr Miyagi for the final time in the series. This character to many of a certain generation is the father and mentor they wish they had, and love him for it. His wisdom, humour and support is humbling to the rest of us.This film returns to its roots as we see Mr Miyagi mentoring a broken girl who is at the stage of graduating to adulthood. Future Oscar winner Hilary Swank is the young lady, her debut movie, and she and Pat Morita strike up an incredible family chemistry that is just so beautiful. She is a perfect stand in as the new student, and becomes like a surrogate daughter to Mr Miyagi who himself has a lot to learn about young ladies too.The story may be clichéd, events contrived and the acting often poor from the bulk of the cast, but the best moments are touching.I really recommend you to watch this film for at least the 'Miyagi Waltz' scene, which personally I think is one of the most beautiful yet simple scenes I've ever seen, and is worth it for the movie time alone. Another is a bowling scene which allows Pat Morita to show his perfect comic-lite touch and wisdom, aided by a group of humble monks. It's just old school light hearted humour.Despite the title, the martial arts is negligible and not of much value in this film (forgettable even), could even have been left out.The music is surprisingly poor (compared to the previous films) and overall the film has the feel of a Sunday afternoon TV movie. This could have been so much better in the hands of a better director. Disappointing as with the lead two stars there could have been so much more in making a more memorable film.For all the film's flaws, there are still moments to admire, and to watch the understated genius of Pat Morita as Mr Miyagi for the final time is a treasure. We'll never see his like again but he is immortalised in this role and will be cherished for eternity for it. He'll never fully know the positive impact he had on the lives of so many with his most important on-screen role. My thanks.

reviews.review_title: Is this movie really as bad as everyone claims? Or, does it deserve the ranking of white belt?
reviews.content: "The Next Karate Kid" (1994), for years, I've heard many people complain about this film over and over again. So, one day, I finally wanted to see what all the fuss was about. I watched it, and it's not quite as bad as everyone makes it out to be. But, it is still a bad movie in it's own right. This film has an uninspired ripoff of a story and average to mediocre acting. The plot does sound interesting at first glance, Mr. Miyagi befriends a girl named Julie whose parents have died in a car accident and is suffering from personal problems. She knows a little bit of karate, but she wants to enhance her karate skills and Mr. Miyagi agrees to teach her. On the one hand, it is interesting to see a female Karate Kid. But, on the other hand, it has a similar plot line to the first movie, just in different context. The friendship between Mr. Miyagi and Julie is genuine and it really does work here in this movie. Probably the weakest aspect in this film are the villains. They did have potential, but they are way too unrealistic and over the top. In some movies that does work, unfortunately, it doesn't work here. Plus, the buildup is not nearly as strong as in the original Karate Kid trilogy. The story did have potential, had the writers just read the script again and maybe did a rewrite, it could have possibly worked. As for the acting, it's just as weak as the storyline. But, not all of the performances were bad though. Pat Morita is perfect, as usual, playing Mr. Miyagi, Hilary Swank does a decent job as Julie and Michael Ironside is fun to watch, but still bad, as the main villain. The rest of the acting is just plain mediocre, which is most likely due to the subpar script. It's a shame, because I've seen the majority of these actors and actresses in other movies and shows. They all can act in other media! What happened to them here? Now, let's get to the positive aspects of this movie. As far as the sets/locations go, they are great and give this film a decent atmosphere. All of the special effects are well-done and still hold up to this day. Finally, the soundtrack composed by Bill Conti is nothing short of fantastic. Bill Conti is one of my top 10 all-time favorite film score composers and this soundtrack is no exception. Bottom line, "The Next Karate Kid" is sadly just a cash-grab. That being said, it does have a few good elements. But it's still, by my standards, a bad movie. I rate this movie 3 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 6 out of 10 IMDB stars. Three stars is the point on my rating scale where it splits the difference between a film being good or bad. "The Next Karate Kid" may be bad, but it's still eons better than the worthless 2010 remake!

'The Next Karate Kid' where do you fit in in the 'Karate Kid' universe?What are you?Let's try and salvage something positive from this movie.This is only the third time I've watched this.Well, I have to ask straight out, why was Ralph Macchio not part of this movie's direction? Who were the brains behind omitting Daniel-San from a Karate Kid storyline and going in a completely different avenue with someone else?Did they not have the smarts for a continuation with the Mr Silver/Barnes storyline?Was Ralph Macchio even consulted about this? A Mr Miyagi movie without Daniel-San? (I'm halfway through reading his "Wax On" book and he's only mentioned 'The Next Karate Kid' once in passing. Can you believe Charlie Sheen auditioned for the role of Daniel-San?)Julie, or Susan, is introduced and full of angst as it's that time of month, I think.We're in Boston by the way and not California. She breaks into her own high school to tend to a broken eagle (fang) wing.There's no mention in this movie, or reference, how Mr Miyagi's "Little Tree" shop became liquidated and placed in the hands of administrators. In fact, there's no references of 'Karate Kid 3' at all in this movie.I love in the 'Karate Kid' movies how they quickly write out the mother figures as they're an inconvenience to the storyline apparently.My mistake, it's a hawk, not an eagle. Hawk's look like eagles.The baddies in this are the Alpha Elites. They're no Cobra Kai. They're more like Columbine High jock thugs who are unlikable and leave no impression. Weak baddies.Miyagi's got his hands full with Maggie Fitzgerald as she's pouty, immature and fiery. She slowly falls for some beefcake and that story takes up a large portion of the movie.Hey, didn't Swank give birth to twins only two weeks ago?So, let me get this straight, Julie-San's grandmother leaves her in the care of Miyagi and the old lady is ordered to travel to California to paint Miyagi's fence & house? Work hard, lady! Sand those floors! What is Miyagi paying you for?Perhaps this movie should have dropped the Karate Kid title and been its own entity? What would it have been called if something else? 'Karate Girl Meets Miyagi?' 'High School Karate Bird Girl?'As if that Dobermann wouldn't have defended its owner.(And I'm searching for something positive in this review?)What's-her-name looks like Taylor Swift at times. I feel she was a tad too old to be cast in this... for a high school student, that is.Praying Mantis' are cool. I once saw a movie where a Mantis was a sensei to some skinny guy and taught him all these stick moves and forearm actions. And I mean an actual insect holding a Bo stick that Donatello uses.Elvis was a black belt? I was unaware of this fact."I can't believe I'm about to eat a cake with chopsticks." Is that even possible? A crumby sponge cake would be hard to maintain but a sticky date pudding is a possibility.My cat, Bungus, is captivated with this releasing of the hawk scene.Pretty clever how Miyagi incorporates karate into a dance lesson.I wonder how many years after the 'Karate Kid 3' this movie took place? And what was Daniel-San doing in that time? (Is that when he converted to his car business in the 'Cobra Kai' series?) So, with this realization are you telling me that Daniel-San and Miyagi actually parted ways? After everything they had been through? Did they part on bad terms after part 3? To think that Miyagi's dream of owning his own tree business failed and went under in only months.The problem with this movie is that there's no build-up.There was no tit for tat reason to have any showdown at the end. Swank wasn't bullied enough to seek any revenge. It's paper-thin.This whole diving off the roof at the ball is embarrassing to say the least. This scene is straight up stupid. What purpose did that serve? Here everyone was having a good time like 'Back to The Future's' Enchantment dance and these nimrods pull some bungee stunt and act like children to show bravado and disrupt everyone's enjoyment?Michael Ironside is a PE teacher at a school and he condones criminal behavior?Brandon - a boy who doesn't cry - takes on whoever the Alpha Elite antagonist is at the end and there's some 'Bloodsport' blindsided moment she learnt earlier in a barn and uses it to justify her assault on whatever this guy's name is. (Actually she does cry in this movie. )And look how quickly Ironside loses his composure at the end against Miyagi. Not one person landed a single hand on Miyagi in any of these movies.I detest the three British songs used in this movie. Woeful choices that don't blend.This movie failed because it didn't include John G. Avildsen's directing.The only returning parties I noticed were Miyagi and Weintraub.All in all, this movie, in the 'Karate Kid' and 'Cobra Kai' universe, is an undercard fight at the start of a pay-per-view event with no audience in attendance to witness it. It lacks soul and body. It's almost like its targeted audience is intended for 5 or 7-year old's.You know what? I just thought of something. It's too late now, I know, but this movie "may" have worked had it been filmed in the same settings and school as the original 'Karate Kid.' To give it "that" feel.Other than Mr Miyagi, none of the surrounds in 'The Next Karate Kid' are 'Karate Kid' related. They're out of their element. Which is a shame.I try to enjoy this movie but it has the 'Karate Kid 2' factor about it in that Sato had to put aside his differences to mourn the loss of Miyagi's father and show respect for a little while. And since Miyagi is in this, I try to put aside my hatred for 'The Next Karate Kid' only out of respect for said person. But, like that washed-up log, I wanna break this movie in half at times and I only watch it out of sympathy because Miyagi's in it. ("DON'T YOU SAY THAT!" You're not gonna cry now, are you?)
'The Next Karate Kid' doesn't possess the magic like 'Cobra Kai' does.'Karate Kid,' with its two sequels and 'Cobra Kai,' have to carry this movie.

reviews.content: The Karate Kid was never a saga focused on martial arts tournaments, but rather on life teachings through an Eastern perspective.There are things about this movie that I liked a lot more than the last two sequels and they found a different way to deliver a similar message to the first movie. The performances have improved, the change of the decade is noticeable in details such as the edition, even the humor shown subtly as special seasoning is better.However, there are also negative things. There are some events that occur without explanation or consequence, such as the jump in benji, among others. There are secondary characters that do not fit well into the story or have a good performance.This fourth film is not the best of the series, but it is not a disaster like the third. Recommended to see once and then look for something better.

TL;DR: Is it a great movie, or it will go down in history as a classic? Hell no! Does it deliver, as a remake of a classic? More less. Does it deliver, as a remake of a classic? More less.  For this movie, Pat Morita got paired with Hilary Swank, instead of Ralph Macchio, which had paired with him during the 80's making one of the family friendly classics of the decade. Hilary Swank does her role without much of an hiccup (she acted way more convincingly than Ralph did), but the role is so weak it makes it hard to come above water. Pat Morita is Mr. Miyagi, and does Mr. Miyagi things, without anything fresh on the character.The antagonists are a replica of the single minded ones from the 1st movie. And the story is, more less what you'd expect from The Karate Kid if it was done with a girl in mind for the "kid" role. It's full of clichés, it's overly long, and it's predictable, in all accounts.Why a 5 then? It has some funny parts, it's a light family friendly movie, full of cliché good messages about friendship, goodness and life. Although as an original movie it fails in all accounts, as a remake, full of female empowering pitches for the teen girls it does its job, and although it seems it was recorded with '84 in mind, although being released one decade later, the message is timeless enough to be relevant in today standards still.Not a must watch, but a pleasant watch for teen girls and boys alike.

Because the last movie of the franchise failed at the box office and was disliked by many fans and critics they tried a fresh restart with a new story-line. Of cause they do not replace Pat Morita as Mr. Miyagi as this would be much too harmful. He is the focus point of the franchise and Daniel LaRusso’s story can be considered finished as he has mastered the critical (life) lessons in the last 3 movies (Until Cobra Kai at least;-). I am in the minority that thinks this is a quite good movie with some mistakes that drag it down. Also I think the first movie which is a cult classic set the bars to high for all the prequels. Sometimes there is a peak that is nearly impossible to surpass or even reach. Again the movie uses themes from an underdog story, teenage drama, clashing philosophies and martial arts. The story starts with Mr. Miyagi traveling to Boston to attend a commendation for Japanese-American soldiers. He visits Louisa Pierce who is the widow of his friend and former commanding officer. He meets Julie who is his friends granddaughter and struggles because of dealing with her parents death. He decides to help her which is the start of a new adventure. The set up is nice and fitting. The later parts are weaker with some exceptions. I would say they try their best but could not reach the appropriate levels to make this a hit or like the first movie. It is not a failure more a case of to much use of the fast forward button for the viewer. Character wise we got good and bad performances. For Hilary Swank this was her first big role and breakthrough. She got recognition and many praised her performance. I agree to that as she fully delivered her role and is a highlight of the movie. Pat Morita as Mr. Miyagi is a staple of the franchise. Always delivering a truly good performance. I cant remember a weak moment in all movies. I am divided for Michael Ironside as Paul Dugan. He does a good job but his character does not fit that good into the movie. Maybe a bit to overdone or cliche (or not enough if you go more into parody territory). I like the monks, Louisa Pierce played by Constance Towers and Michael Cavalieri as Ned Randall with some bad scenes. In total it is a solid performance but in combination with the script there are too many weaknesses. To be fair other were far more critical here and I see their points. Maybe I am far less critical but I can not prove that my opinion is more valuable than theirs and vice versa. Overall the movie was not strong enough to safe the franchise. I liked it but it has some weaknesses that drag it down. I think that I enjoy the two main characters saved the movie for me. I am however not sure if I can recommend it to others.

I quite liked this one.There may not be anything outstanding, or even massively good, about 'The Next Karate Kid', but I actually felt content with what I had just watched when the end credits came along. It turns into a sweet story, even after a fairly rocky start.The villains are meh, a little iffy but fine... far better than those from 'The Karate Kid Part III', that's for sure. Pat Morita (Mr. Miyagi) is a little cliché-filled but still super endearing and likeable. A young Hilary Swank, in her first major film role, brings a solid performance as Julie. At first I wasn't convinced, but by the end I felt like I saw a positive journey with the character.In my opinion, it's the best sequel to 1984's 'The Karate Kid'. That's a big surprise, considering the downward trajectory of the preceding two. Don't get me wrong, it's close to being a not so good film. However, for me, it just about floats above the required marker. I like it, can't lie.

I take it that it was simply a case of milking the brand and they wanted to make some more money from the series. This was so unnecessary. For me, a bad movie that I don't recommend even to fans of the franchise.

If anything, this last instalment gives a new light to the franchise by introducing the wonderfully played Julie. There is something to be said for The Next Karate Kid going for some other directions after 2 sequels of the same formula.
